article_title: 'Medical necessity' decried as a loophole for insuring the mentally ill
article_text:
'Medical necessity' decried as a loophole for insuring the mentally ill Plans accused of using loophole to deny treatment

Photo: Elizabeth Conley, Staff A local mother, Jackie, is caught between trying to care for her...

At 12, Jackie's daughter threatened suicide. By 14, she had been hospitalized three times in a psychiatric facility and diagnosed with severe bipolar disorder. Now 15, she has started to hit her mother.

article_metadata.description: Jackie says doctors told her what her daughter needs after release is months of intense residential treatment to fully calm and stabilize her in a safe environment.  Jackie, whose last name is being withheld to protect her daughter's privacy, said her child's doctor and the insurer became locked in battle after the company said outpatient care would suffice.  Seven years ago this month, President George W. Bush signed a law requiring any insurance policy that included mental health treatment to be equal in coverage to medical treatment, in an effort to stop the long-standing practice of charging higher co-pays for mental health care, limiting treatment or denying it outright.  The measure was further strengthened in 2010 with the passage of the Affordable Care Act, which extended federal parity requirements to individual and small-group plans and mandated mental health and substance abuse be covered in any plan sold on federal marketplace or state exchanges.  [...] the lofty goal of equality has fallen far short of its promise, providers, patients and policy experts say.  Not even close, says Glenn Urbach, executive director of the National Alliance on Mental Illness Greater Houston, a local affiliate of the education and advocacy organization.  By such logic the rate of denials for mental health treatment and medical treatment should be roughly the same.  The NAMI survey of nearly 3,000 mental health patients and their families found that they were being denied mental health care on the basis of medical necessity twice as often as they were general medical care.  No one benefits when these needs aren't addressed, so health plans work to ensure their enrollees get the right care at the right time and in the right setting.  Comparing mental health coverage to medical coverage is like comparing apples to oranges.  A treatment plan for diabetes, for example, is very different from a patient seeking care for depression, Jay says.  [...] Dr. Dan McCoy, divisional senior vice president and chief medical officer for the insurer, said his company is "committed to mental health parity very strongly" and has a system in place where psychiatrists working for the company review mental health treatment options much as their company-paid physicians review medical care.  [...] certain managed care groups are well known within the Houston behavioral care community of having a "predictably higher rate of denials" and a "higher hassle factor," says Dr. George Santos, chief medical officer and executive medical director at Houston Behavioral Hospital.  Urbach says this is where the gap between medical and mental health care widens: If someone had cancer and an oncologist prescribed chemotherapy for three months or six months everyone would expect that a health insurance company would allow a doctor to do his job.  In an emailed statement, a Blue Cross Blue Shield spokeswoman noted that reviews in psychiatric care cases are conducted "by a board-certified psychiatrist" and said the company "fully supports mental health parity and designs and implements all members' benefits accordingly."  Texas ranks 47th out of 50 states and the District of Columbia in access to mental health care, and 50th in the number of mental health providers with only one for every 1,757 in the state, according to a study by Mental Health America.
article_metadata.author.name: By Jenny Deam
